title: Mind Candy on track to double sales as it signs up Brian Blessed for children's story app
text:
Children-focused technology company Mind Candy has secured a further £2.8m cash injection as it targets doubling revenues this year and starts signing up famous names for its children’s storytime app.

The London firm, one of the early poster-children of Shoreditch’s Silicon Roundabout, said it expects to double sales this year, from around £5m to £10m, according to accounts filed to Companies House.

The further investment came from early investor Accel Partners, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm that first backed Mind Candy more than a decade ago. However, losses also widened amid a renewed period of investment, growing to £3.8m.

Mind Candy was a star of London’s technology scene in the mid 2000s, developing its online Moshi Monsters game series to appeal to young web users.

Founded in 2003, at one stage it was turning over more than £45m and had nearly 200 staff. But it was hit by the rise of mobile gaming and saw revenues fall, dropping as low as £3.5m and cutting headcount to 22.

Now, the firm is growing again, according to Ian Chambers, who took over from founder Michael Acton Smith in 2016.

The company has launched new products in recent years. A website called Petlandia, which turns pictures of children’s pets into story books; and Moshi Twilight. Moshi Twilight includes bedtime stories and soothing sounds to help put children to sleep.
